title: 113_hr2875
content: The Waterfront of Tomorrow Act of 2013 may be cited as the official title for this legislation. It includes provisions for conducting studies. The Waterfront of Tomorrow Act of 2013, also known as the official title for this legislation, includes provisions for conducting a study on measures to improve flood protection and climate resilience for New York City. The study will assess traditional engineering solutions and alternative approaches such as oyster reef restoration and tidal wetland construction to reduce storm surge impacts and retain stormwater. The cost, time, and potential impact of implementing these measures will also be identified. The Waterfront of Tomorrow Act of 2013 mandates a study to evaluate flood protection and climate resilience measures for New York City, including traditional engineering solutions and alternative approaches like oyster reef restoration and tidal wetland construction. The study will assess costs, timeframes, potential impacts, and make recommendations for the most effective measures to protect coastal communities and critical infrastructure from events like Hurricane Sandy. Coordination with other related studies is required, and a report to Congress is due within 18 months of the Act's enactment. The Waterfront of Tomorrow Act of 2013 mandates a study to evaluate flood protection and climate resilience measures for New York City. The Secretary shall transmit a report to Congress on the results of the study within 18 months. The Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency will conduct a study on the environmental impact of major disasters on the waters of the United States. The Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency will conduct studies on major disasters to determine if industrial facilities caused pollution in waterways and how to prevent future incidents. A report on the study results must be submitted to Congress within 180 days of a major disaster declaration. The Administrator will report study results on major disasters to Congress within 180 days of a disaster declaration. The term "major disaster" is defined in the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act. SEC. 3 amends goals for the national freight network to include accounting for socioeconomic and environmental impacts. It also ensures that ports and harbors are part of the network. SEC. 4 focuses on next-generation ports. Improvements to port infrastructure and intermodal rail and highway networks are authorized through grants to states and local governments. Local preferences and environmental concerns must be considered to minimize disruptions and adverse impacts. A green port designation for ports meeting environmental standards is established, with grants and technical assistance available. The Environmental Protection Agency will establish a green port designation for ports meeting environmental standards. The Maritime Administration can provide grants and technical assistance to green ports for implementing innovations to reduce environmental impacts. SEC. 5. WATERFRONTS AS MAIN STREETS. The Secretary of Commerce will establish a grant program for environmentally sustainable waterfront projects. States and local governments can apply for grants by submitting applications meeting specified criteria. Priority will be given to projects that promote economic growth or enhance environmental sustainability. The maximum grant amount will be determined by the Secretary. The Secretary may award grants to State or local governments for projects that aim to generate economic growth, create jobs, or improve environmental sustainability in waterfront areas. The maximum grant amount is $10,000,000, and recipients must submit annual reports on performance measures for 3 years. The Federal share of project costs cannot exceed 75 percent.
